title: RL32541
content: The 9/11 Commission found that al Qaeda terrorists exploited weaknesses in aviation security, including a pre-screening process focused on bombers, lax checkpoint screening, lack of in-flight security measures, compliance with hijackers, and a lack of protocols for the FAA. The 9/11 Commission identified weaknesses in aviation security, including compliance with hijackers and a lack of protocols for coordinated responses to multiple hijackings. They attributed these vulnerabilities to a failure of imagination among senior policymakers and agencies responsible for intelligence, national defense, and aviation security. Before September 11, 2001, aviation security experts underestimated the likelihood of suicide hijackings, leading to a lack of specific actions taken to defend against this threat. Congressional oversight of aviation security was also lacking, with a focus on airport congestion and passenger service instead. Before September 11, 2001, congressional oversight of aviation security was lacking as Congress focused on airport congestion and passenger service. The 9/11 Commission noted that Congress concentrated on improving air service with no focus on terrorism. After the attacks, Congress swiftly passed the Aviation and Transportation Security Act to address security weaknesses. The Aviation and Transportation Security Act (ATSA) was passed by Congress after the 9/11 attacks to address aviation security weaknesses. It established the Transportation Security Administration (TSA) to oversee security in all modes of transportation, including federal security screeners at airports, explosive detection screening for checked bags, air marshals on high-risk flights, and hardened cockpit doors. The Aviation and Transportation Security Act (ATSA) established the TSA to oversee security in all transportation modes, focusing on aviation security.
